claim.text: Meta Agent Search can discover agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed agents across multiple domains.
claim.exact_quote: The results across multiple domains demonstrate that Meta Agent Search can discover agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed agents.

evidence.evidence_text: Meta Agent Search can discover agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed agents across multiple domains such as Reading Comprehension and Math with substantial improvements over hand-designed agents.
evidence.limitations: Performance improvement is domain-dependent and less substantial in the Science and Multi-task domains.
evidence.exact_quote: The results across multiple domains demonstrate that Meta Agent Search can discover agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed agents.

claim.text: Discovered agents improve F1 scores by 13.6/100 in reading comprehension and accuracy rates by 14.4% in math tasks.
claim.exact_quote: Our agents improve F1 scores on reading comprehension tasks by 13.6/100 and accuracy rates on math tasks by 14.4%.

evidence.evidence_text: Discovered agents showed improvements in F1 scores by 13.6/100 in reading comprehension and accuracy rates by 14.4% in math tasks.
evidence.limitations: Data specific to these domains, may not generalize across all tasks.
evidence.exact_quote: Improvements in F1 scores by 13.6/100 and accuracy rates by 14.4%, respectively.

conclusion.limitations: reported improvements specific to certain domains may not generalize

claim.text: Meta Agent Search demonstrates transferability across domains, with significant improvements observed even in domains different from the ones they were trained on.
claim.exact_quote: The experiments demonstrate that the discovered agents not only perform well when transferring across similar domains but also exhibit strong performance when transferring across dissimilar domains.

evidence.evidence_text: Agents discovered in the Math domain could be transferred to non-math domains, outperforming or matching state-of-the-art hand-designed baselines.
evidence.limitations: Performance varies when agents are transferred across domains.
evidence.exact_quote: Agents discovered in the math domain can be transferred to non-math domains, outperforming (in Reading Comprehension and Multi-task) or match (in Science) the state-of-the-art hand-designed agent baselines.

conclusion.limitations: limited evidence on the extent of domain transferability beyond math and reading comprehension

claim.text: Meta Agent Search innovates by using multiple Chain-of-Thoughts (COTs) to generate possible answers, refine them, and ensemble the best answers, a novel design pattern that emerged during the process.
claim.exact_quote: An important design pattern emerged in iteration 3 where it uses multiple COTs to generate possible answers, refines them, and finally ensembles the best answers.

evidence.evidence_text: An important design pattern involving multiple Chain-of-Thoughts (COTs) for answer generation and refinement emerged during Meta Agent Search.
evidence.limitations: Documented as a single case, may require further evidence to validate consistency of emergence.
evidence.location: Results and Analysis section on innovation
evidence.exact_quote: An important design pattern emerged in iteration 3 where it uses multiple COTs to generate possible answers, refines them, and finally ensembles the best answers.

conclusion.limitations: need for empirical data on the comparative analysis of multiple COTs effectiveness versus single COT patterns

claim.text: The sophisticated feedback mechanism adopted by the best-discovered agent illustrates the progression of Meta Agent Search in discovering increasingly complex and effective agent designs.
claim.exact_quote: The best-discovered agent is shown in Figure 3b, where a complex feedback mechanism is adopted to refine answers more effectively.

evidence.evidence_text: The best-discovered agent adopted a complex feedback mechanism for effective answer refinement illustrating the progression and innovation in agent design.
evidence.limitations: Focuses on a singular best case; does not provide evidence of widespread applicability.
evidence.location: Results and Analysis section on feedback mechanisms
evidence.exact_quote: The best-discovered agent is shown where a complex feedback mechanism is adopted to refine answers more effectively.

conclusion.limitations: specifics of the feedback mechanism and its scalability across domains not fully detailed

claim.text: ADAS is identified as a newly forming research area that aims to automatically invent novel building blocks and design powerful agentic systems.
claim.exact_quote: In this paper, we describe a newly forming research area Automated Design of Agentic Systems (ADAS).

evidence.evidence_text: ADAS, including Meta Agent Search, represents a newly forming research area focusing on the automated invention of novel building blocks and design of powerful agentic systems.
evidence.limitations: While it defines a new area, the impact and future success of ADAS are speculative at this stage.
evidence.location: Introduction and Section 2 on ADAS definition
evidence.exact_quote: We describe a newly forming research area, Automated Design of Agentic Systems (ADAS), which aims to automatically create powerful agentic system designs.

conclusion.limitations: ADAS as a research area's impact on future design of agentic systems remains speculative

claim.text: Improved understanding of Foundation Models (FMs) through ADAS leads to insights such as the need for simpler feedback mechanisms in advanced models.
claim.location: Towards a Better Understanding of FMs
claim.exact_quote: For example, the best agent with GPT-3.5 involves a complex feedback mechanism, but when we transfer to other advanced models, the agent with a simpler feedback mechanism but more refinement becomes a better agent.

evidence.evidence_text: Improved understanding of Foundation Models (FMs) through ADAS indicates a necessity for simpler feedback mechanisms in more advanced models for better performance.
evidence.limitations: Based on comparative performance of different agents across models, may not generalize to all cases.
evidence.location: Towards a Better Understanding of FMs section
evidence.exact_quote: This shows that GPT-3.5 may have a worse capability in evaluating and refining the answers, so it needs a complex feedback mechanism for better refinement, while other advanced models benefit more from a simpler feedback mechanism.

conclusion.limitations: conclusions drawn from indirect insights, lacks direct comparative analysis
